text: I'm John Harwood with the New York Times
and CNBC 2008 may prove better than most
political years for surviving charges of
flip-flopping and Barack Obama and John
McCain have both set out to test their
luck what makes this environment more
forgiving is the presidential style of
the incumbent george w bush has been
steadfast on iraq tax cuts in the role
of government and his low approval
rating show voters want something new
mccain showed his flexibility early in
the campaign embracing the bush tax cuts
he had opposed in the senate last week
obama scrapped his commitment to
negotiate an agreement with mccain to
remain within the public financing
system this fall each candidate will use
these shifts in position to attack the
others trustworthiness and hope voters
care more about the shift than about the
position voters sometimes let flip-flops
go ronald reagan won reelection even
though he raised taxes in 1982 after
cutting them a year earlier but other
times they don't george HW bush lost the
presidency after abandoning his no new
taxes pledge and john kerry paid a
significant price four years ago from
voters judgment that he'd reversed field
on the iraq war the summer transition
from primary to general election is
right four ships in emphasis if not
outright flip-flops since beating
Hillary Clinton with populist rhetoric
on trade and taxes Obama has declared
himself a free trader while signaling
the possibility of cutting corporate
taxes and delaying some tax hikes on the
wealthy the common thread as with
Obama's decision to avoid the spending
limits of public financing is the
portrayal of the Illinois Senator as a
pragmatic rather than ideologically
rigid politician with last week's
decision to abandon his support for a
federal moratorium on offshore oil
drilling McCain signal the same thing
that he'd respond boldly to four dollar
gallon gas the candidates have four more
months for repositioning as they chase
swing voters McCain might may find
additional flip-flops harder to resist
in this month NBC news/wall Street
Journal poll majorities of voters rated
both men highly for being honest and
straightforward but Obama enjoyed a
double-digit edge in the proportion
rating him highly for sharing your
positions on the issues in the
presidential race over
all obama led forty-seven percent to
forty-one percent
